# 1600\n
{Oxford, Bodleian Library Laud Misc 108, part 1, fols. 1r-200v, hand A: Life of Christ, Infancy of Christ, South English Legendary}\n
C13b2-C14a1\n
429 221 N\n
{=W Oxon=}\n
{=Sample tagged: fols. 1r-22r, 31v-41v: Life of Christ, Infancy of\n
Christ, SS. Saints Barnabe, John the Baptist, James the Great, Oswald and Edward=}\n
{=Script - Textura semi-quadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The texts written by scribe A seem to be in very similar language\n
indeed even down to very characteristic details (e.g. zW- for OE hw-\n
GUOD for "good") and amalgamation into a single text profile seems justified\n
Such differences as there are (e.g. Life - preferred HEO "they",\n
TWEI "two", -zT- for OE -ht and FETTE "fetch" against Infancy - HUY, TWO\n
-zHT and FECHCHE) can be put down to constrained selection from\n
exemplar preferences. The figura for Z used by this scribe is of the\n
barred type and is Z-shaped not yogh-shaped. I have realised it\n
throughout as Z. I assume where it does not imply [z] that it stands\n
for [(e)t] or [(e)8] (8 is phonetic theta phonetic edh) from the\n
Latin and A-N abbreviation for <et>. Cf. WIZ is "with". Punctus\n
elevatus is not very different from colon in this hand, but there\n
usually seems to be a slight off-stroke to the upper mark of the two,\n
so I realise all examples as .\' rather than : throughout. There are\n
dots (or perhaps prickings - it is hard to tell from the microfilm)\n
marking the end of the writing space for each verse line.\n
Occasionally, when the writing comes right up to them, it is\n
impossible to tell for sure that they are not intended as punctus.\n
But even in these cases, unless there seems a particular reason to do\n
so, I do not count them as punctuation marks=}\n
{281}\n
{Oxford, Bodleian Library Laud Misc 108, part 1, hand A, fols. 1r-10v, Life of Christ}\n
{13b2-C14a1}\n
{429 221}\n
{~f1r~}\n
{=text begins imperfectly. This item, \'The Life of Christ\', and the next,\n
\'The Infancy of Christ\', are numbered items 8 and 9, suggesting that\n
items 1-7 as well as the beginning of 8 have been lost from the\n
beginning of the MS before the present fol. 1r. The end of no. 8 was\n
also probably lost at the same time, as the note in the bottom margin of\n
fol. 10v suggests that the end of the poem was probably misbound at one\n
time into the earlier part of the book. See below before f11r.\n
Punctuation is confined to mid-line punctus elevatus=}\n

{=Two-line coloured decorated initial *H with the first element\n
extending up two further lines\' height in the left margin=}\n
!_CO\n
{=CO begins the next word, but there is here a sizeable hole in the\n
parchment here, which the scribe accommodates for the next seven\n
lines. Here he breaks off the word and starts it again on the\n
other side of the hole, leaving a redundant CO in the hither side=}\n

{=ins, by a different hand=}\n
{=There is a textual problem here. The last word of the line Needs to\n
rhyme with "to", postposition in next line - so something is missing.\n
In the MS TO (for "two", "too"?) added by another hand. But the text\n
corresponds with the Vulgate "et in his omnibus" (AV has "besides all\n
this"). "Also" seems the most likely paraphrase. Horstmann (1873)\n
suggests DO or TO=}\n

$earthgrine/n<pr_EORyE+GREO[N]E $grine/n<pr-k_+GREO[N]E\n
{=N looks like U and Horstmann (1873) reads EORyEGREOUE without\n
comment. But the sense "earth-quake" is needed and the only\n
possible reading would seem to be N (perhaps the scribe himself\n
was not familiar with the word). The medial EO is puzzling, but\n
the etymology of the second element is said by OED to be unknown\n
and there are citations with medial E as well as with I. Given\n
that OE /y/ can be spelled <i>/<e>/<u> in ME and the <u>/<eo>\n
interchange in SWML, could the word be from OE gryn "evil,\n
affliction"?}\n

{>)(VERTE AD ISTUD SIGNUm [4 dots in a diamond shape] IN ISTO LIBRO\n
IN PRINCIPIO LIBRI \\ & IBI IUVENIETIS PLUS DE PASSIONE DoMinI POST\n
ASSUMTIONEm \\ SanCtE MARIE})(>}\n
{=ins, in bottom margin in a slightly later hand. This note\n
suggests that the rest of the poem may at one time have been\n
misbound at the beginning of the MS. This cannot now be verified\n
as the first 7 items of the MS and the beginning of this item\n
(no. 8) are lost=}\n
{\\\\}\n
{283}\n
{Oxford, Bodleian Library Laud Misc 108, part 1, hand A, fols. 11r-22r, Infancy of Christ}\n
{C13b2-C14a1}\n
{429 221}\n
{~f11ra~}\n
{=This item \'The Infancy of Christ\', is numbered item 9 (cf. the previous\n
in the same hand, \'The Life of Christ, numbered no. 8). This suggests that\n
items 1-7 as well as the beginning of 8 have been lost from the\n
beginning of the MS before the present fol. 1r. The rhymes in this\n
verse are often very poor - half rhyme is plentiful as well as\n
assonance. In most cases it is hard to see, even if the original dialect\n
were different, how the rhymes could ever have been other than rough.\n
I have, however in almost all cases marked the words in rhyming\n
position in the usual way as the intention seems to have been to\n
write in rhyming couplets and however rough, the words chosen are\n
clearly affected by the necessity of producing something like a rhyme.\n
\'The Infancy of Christ\' is in the same hand as \'The Life of Christ\'.\n
The scribe uses a rather smaller version of his script and here writes\n
in two columns rather than across the page. There is no punctuation,\n
other than paragraph markers, in the verse. The prose section headings\n
do occasionally have some punctuation=}\n
{> para (\'*ICI CO\\MENCE LE EN\\FAUNCE IHesU Cr^IST .\'(>}\n
{=ins, in central margin=}\n
$in{m}/pr_*I*N\n
{=Enlarged coloured, decorated initial *I of nine lines\' depth extending\n
down the left margin=}\n

$/RTApl_yAT\n
$see/vSpt23_SE\n
{=The syntax demands plural not singular. This scribe\'s language has\n
usual (I)SEIzE(N) for pret pl of "see" but it is hard to see how else to\n
parse this. Horstmann (1875) thinks yAT is an error for yER and\n
presumably would read SE as inf. But this scribe has SEO(N) usually\n
for the infinitive. So something seems to be not quite right with the\n
line=}\n
$/DesOd_yIS\n
$virtue/nplOd{rh}_VERTU+ES $/plnOd_+ES\n
{\\}\n
$ac/cj_*AKE\n
$fall/vSpt23_FULL+EN $/vSpt23_+EN\n
$adown/av_A-DOUN $a-/xp-av_A-\n
$as/av_ASE\n
$dead/ajpl_DED+E $/plaj_+E\n
$ewe/npl{rh}_EW+ES $/pln{rh}_+ES\n
{\\}\n
$/neg-v(>av)_*NE\n
$see/vSpt23_SEI+EN $/vSpt23[V]_+EN\n

$recet/n_RECET\n
{=Horstmann and MED take this to be a miswriting of RETET past\n
participle of retten "ascribe to" or "be guilty of". But the\n
expected form for such a past participle in this scribe\'s\n
language would be RETTED. Moreover, nobody thinks Joseph committed the\n
murder . They all know Jesus did. The MS reading is clearly RECET and\n
the AF word receite, recet, reset meaning "refuge, protection, harbouring\n
(of an offender))" would carry the truer sense here, with the\n
committer of the murder (DETH) being understood=}\n
$of/pr_OF\n

$bear/vpsp{rh}_BER+INGE $/vpsp{rh}_+INGE\n
{=So in the MS. The original G has been roughly corrected to D by\n
addition of a curve ascender. I have kept G because I take it to be at\n
least the first thought of the original scribe. The fact that the rhyme is\n
spoiled would be enough to cause a later correction but need not imply\n
that -INGE alongside -INDE was not an allowable spelling also for the present\n
participle - indeed it occurs elsewhere in this scribe\'s output=}\n

{~f20ra~}\n
$oepa?/vpt13_*HEP+EDE $/vpt13[P]_+EDE\n
{"cried out (against)"}\n
\'_*IHesuM\n
$little/aj-voc_LUTTLE\n
$ribaud/n-voc{rh}_*RIBAUT\n
{=Horstmann (1875) suggests for MS HEPEDE either "he paid" or\n
that it is an error for HE SEDE "he said". Assuming "paid", he\n
also punctuates the line with a colon after LUTTLE as if to\n
imply "he satisfied Jesus little: Ribaud etc". But the form in\n
which the word is written doesn\'t suggest the word "paid", while\n
"said" makes little sense. In the context of a verbal assault\n
(SAUzT) it seems most likely to be a verb meaning "cry out". For a\n
possibility, though it would have to assume an intrusive initial <h>,\n
see MED s.v. e:pen v. OED s.v. epe v. (only one citation from Orm).\n
It is just possible perhaps that HEPEDE is from the verb he:apian\n
in the sense "load onto, overwhelm". In either interpretation, the\n
syntax would have to include LUTTLE as part of the address - "little\n
worthless thing"=}\n
{\\}\n
$/TN_*yE\n

$/Dat<pr_yAT\n
$country/n<pr{rh}_CONTREZ\n
{=sic. Note that this is an important early citation of the \'contreth\'\n
spelling (borne out by the rhyme on BETH) suggesting also long open\n
[e] and unvoiced final fricative. This is from eOF contrede, otherwise\n
not recorded in English until the 15th cent. See Derek Britton,\n
Neophilologus 76 (1992), 283-89. This citation may have been missed in\n
the dictionaries because of lack of understanding that in eME (and\n
regularly in this hand) the equivalent of -eth could be spelled -ez=}\n
{\\}\n

{Oxford, Bodleian Library, Laud Misc 108, part 1, hand A: fols. 31v-41v, Saints Barnabe, John the Baptist, James the Great, Oswald and Edward}\n
{C13b2-C14a1}\n
{429 221}\n
{=Fols. 1r-200v are all in hand A. The Life of Christ 1r-10v and Infancy of\n
Christ 11r-22r are tagged as 281 and 283. These five saints\' lives\n
(numbered items 13-17 in the MS, are amalgamated with the first two\n
texts as no. 1600. Punctuation is confined to mid-line punctus\n
elevatus=}\n

\n
# 282\n
{Oxford, Bodleian Library, Laud Misc 108, hand B, fols. 200v-203v: Debate between Body and Soul}\n
C13b2-C14a1\n
553 280 N\n
{=Ely (Cambs)=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - Textura semi-quadrata=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The text starts after the end of South English Legendary (in Hand A)\n
halfway through fol. 200v. The first 6 \'stanzas\' (24 long lines) are on fol.\n
200v written tightly. With Hand A\'s contribution above there are 45 lines to\n
this page. From fol. 201r the writing is more spaced with only 34 long lines to\n
the page. This gives it a look of being in a different hand, but the whole\n
text is in fact written by scribe B. Presumably he wanted to finish at the end of\n
a verso folio (which he does) and calculated back how many lines he would need\n
to get into the first half folio. The long lines rhyme aaaa but the mid-line\n
also rhymes bbbb, so if the verse were set out in short lines each \'stanza\'\n
would be abababab. The verse is not, however, organised in stanzas, there being\n
no gaps between the long lines. The punctuation is confined to punctus elevatus\n
(occasionally missing, and once a punctus) marking the mid-line rhyme. In the\n
first \'stanza\' only, the line ends are linked by a squiggly brace, presumably to show\n
the 4-line rhyming structure=}\n
{~f200v~}\n
$as/cj_[]LS\n
{=Space is left for a large initial *A not carried out=}\n
$/P11N_I\n
$licgan/vSpt11_LAY\n
$on{t}/pr_IN\n

$have/vpt12_HA+DDEST $/vpt12[V]_+DDEST\n
$in{m}/pr_IN\n
$destrele:de/npl<pr{rh}_DESTER-LEDD+ES $le:de/npl<pr-k{rh}_-LEDD+ES $/pln<pr_+ES\n
{=Linow (1889) emends to "that thou about in destre (i.e. right hand)\n
leads", taking "about" from the Auchinleck text which is, however,\n
somewhat different here. I assume that the Laud text here is correct\n
and the compound is referring to the trappings/bridle/leads that were\n
suitable for a quality charger or war-horse - destr(i)er. See MED s.v.\n
le:de n. 1 (or less likely) ladde n. 2) for the second part of the\n
compound. MED following Linow\'s text quotes this as the single\n
example of "destre" used in English for "right hand". But I think the\n
compound interpretation is more likely here=}\n
{\\}\n
$/P12GNpl+C_yI\n

$&/cj_*AND\n
$sink?/vSpt23_SENK+E $/vSpt23_+E\n
{=The vocalism is troublesome here (one would expect SUNK-), but it is\n
difficult to see what else this could be read as. The sense of the whole\n
clause  would be "descended upon him on all sides". The other versions\n
closest to Laud (Auchinleck and Vernon - neither of them in LAEME) have\n
nothing helpful, and the readings are all problematic suggesting that\n
there may be some textual corruption here, especially as this half line\n
seems to bear little relation to what comes before (the torture of being forced\n
to drink hot lead) or after=}\n
$about{p}/pr_A+BOUTEN $a-/xp-pr_A+\n
{=A letter (perhaps U) erased between O and U=}\n
$/P13<prI_HIM\n
$abroad/av{rh}_A-BROD\n
{"on all sides"}\n
{=The alternative would be to read A BROD as "a brood [of foul devils]".\n
But SENKE formally can hardly be singular whether it is from the strong\n
verb sincan (where one would expect SANK with no final E) for past tense\n
or an -eth type ending if there were a switch to present tense. Equally\n
if it were from the  weak verb scencan "to plunge, drown" one would\n
expect an -eth type ending in present tense and an -ed type in the past\n
tense. But in any case this text does not have S for OE sc. For this\n
verb one would also therefore expect initial SCH- and the verb "sink"\n
seems the only possible candidate=}\n
{\\}\n

\n
# 285\n
{Oxford, Bodleian Library, Laud Misc 108, fols. 204r-219va, hand C: Havelok}\n
C14a1\n
554 300 S\n
{=W Norfolk=}\n
{=Sample represents the whole of Havelok (fols. 204r-219va). King Horn\n
(fols. 219va-228r) is also in hand C, but in mixed language - Norfolk\n
with a much more southerly ingredient. KH has not been tagged=}\n
{=Script - Textura semiquadrata=}\n
{=Status - the manuscript text has no punctuation. New sections are\n
indicated by enlarged blue initials decorated with red - as noted in the\n
tagged text. Smithers (1987) does not individually note these capitals\n
nor do his section breaks always follow those indicated by them. Tagging\n
notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=Note that Smithers (1987) expands abbreviations silently, except\n
where the titulus (n or m as required) is shown in italics to\n
differentiate it from hyper-metrical -en. As usual I mark all\n
manuscript abbreviations and only capitalise where the manuscript\n
has capitals or littorae notabiliores - mostly only at the beginnings\n
of lines. The shapes of thorn and <y> are occasionally rather similar, but\n
usually are distinguished, thorn has a slightly raised ascender\n
which tends to bend back and <y> is usually dotted. The shapes of\n
C and T are very similar. The common CT is usually ligatured, the\n
scribe giving the shaft of T following C a much taller stroke. When\n
not ligatured, T usually has a top stroke to the left as well as to the\n
right of the shaft. Smithers assumes the letter to be C when the left\n
part of the top stroke is missing and emends to T. But there are\n
sufficient numbers of cases where C is T-shaped and T is C-shaped for\n
the assumption that the figurae were, at least to a certain extent,\n
interchangeable. I have therefore tended to follow Smithers\'\n
\'emendations\' though have not called them emendations or put them in\n
square brackets. I have noted, however, if the letter T is unusually\n
C-like or vice-versa. The scribe tends to make his minim strokes\n
forming N, M and U separately with no clear or consistent joining at the\n
top for M and N or at the foot for U. He sometimes uses an oblique\n
hairline stroke to differentiate I, but not commonly. This means that\n
context is often the only way to decide which letter is intended. This\n
only becomes a serious problem with the word "knight" which is sometimes\n
spelled KINCT with clear hairline stroke on the first minim. This\n
matches similar CIN- spellings in Layamon and elsewhere and must be\n
treated as a genuine orthographic form whatever its phonological\n
implications may be (see Laing & Lass 2005). There are many\n
instances of the word, however where the three minims making up -NI-\n
or -IN- in this word are quite impossible to differentiate. In those\n
cases I have transcribed the word with the historically expected\n
spelling KNI- and have only transcribed KIN- where there are strong\n
positive reasons for the reading=}\n
{~f204ra~}\n
{>()[...]ELOK QU[...] *REX *ANGLIE . [line fillers] *ET DENEMARCHIE)(>}\n
{=ins, in top margin and the beginning lost by trimming=} \n
$hearken/v-imp22K2_*HERKN+ET $/v-imp22K2_+ET\n
{=Two-line blue initial *H, decorated with red=}\n

$faela/vpt13_FEL+EDE $/vpt13[L]_+EDE\n
{=Smithers (1987) and Skeat-Sisam (1956) follow Onions (who himself\n
credits Tolkien - see Philologica: the Malone Anniversary Studies\n
(1949), p. 157) in taking this to mean "terrify" or "scare" and\n
cite OI faela, faelda. MED takes the word to be from OE fe:olan\n
"approach", "have to do with". Although the letter F in MED was\n
edited very early, it was published after the Onions article.\n
Holthausen (1901) takes the word to be a form of "follow"=}\n

$knight/n{rh}_KINCTH\n
{=sic - with clear oblique stroke indicating I on the first minim. The\n
second and third minims are formed as N with clear link at the top,\n
there is no link between the first and second minims. Cf similar\n
spellings in Layamon. The phonology of these spellings is not clear.\n
Smithers (1987) notes the spelling here (line 77) and emends to KNICTH. He\n
does not note any other examples of KIN- in this word, but see some\n
probable others below and cf Laing & Lass (2005)=}\n
{\\}\n
$/P13NM_*HE\n

$can/vpt23_COUyE\n
$ge:man/vi{rh}_YEM+E $/vi{rh}_+E\n
{=The above seems to me to make better sense of these lines than\n
previous efforts. It avoids Holthausen\'s supposition that the HEM\n
refers to enemies and that therefore some lines before must be missing.\n
Skeats\' radical emendation is rendered unnecessary, and it sticks to\n
the MS reading without invoking Smithers\' (1987) "delayed preposition".\n
The translation would be "If.. she could take control of England and do it\n
into the hands of those who were pleasing to her and could protect her\n
person...". This identifies yAR HIRE WERE Q~ME with the thousand men\n
by her side=}\n
{\\}\n
$/neg-v(>av)_*NE\n

{=Holthausen (1901) emends *ME away altogether. Skeat-Sisam (1956)\n
and Smithers (1987) emend to *NE, but the context makes the use of\n
the interjection quite natural and I\'m not even sure what weight\n
the emended *NE would be supposed to carry=}\n

$adread/vpp{rh}_A+DRED $a-/xp-v_A+\n
{=Smithers (1987) reads ADRAD with no editorial comment. Skeat-Sisam\n
(1956) says the reading is ADRED altered to ADRAD. The last two\n
letters are squashed together somewhat, but the penultimate is\n
certainly not A and appears to me to be E-shaped. If there has\n
been any attempt at alteration I don\'t think it is by the main\n
scribe. ADRED obviously does not provide a pure rhyme with GAD\n
which presumably explains the editorial readings. But cf. ADRED\n
in line 1259 rhyming with BED. The main scribe clearly has ADRED\n
as one possible variant and he is not overly squeamish about\n
spoiling rhymes=}\n
{\\}\n

$bebed/viK2{rh}_BE-BEDD+E $be-/xp-v_BE- $/viK2{rh}_+E\n
{=Using the verb (< OE beddian) is a common way of saying "provide a bed\n
for" in ME. The prefixed variant is apparently unique however, and BE-\n
rather than BI- is not this scribe\'s usual spelling. Smithers (1987)\n
makes no comment on the word although he prints BEBEDDE as a single\n
form. He does not gloss it. Skeat-Smithers (1956) is worried by the lack of\n
other citations and BE- rather than BI- and suggests that the letters have\n
been erroneously repeated and that the word should be emended to BEDDE.\n
An alternative would be to take BEDDE as the noun and translate "Nor did\n
he richly for them by (in respect to) bed". However, this scribe\'s usual\n
form for "by" is also BI not BE=}\n
{\\}\n

$see/vSpt13_SAW\n
$&/cj_AND\n
$thereby{p}/av-k_yE-BI $by{p}/pr-k_-BI\n
{=sic. yE is more likely to be an error for "there" (as Holthausen\n
(1901) and Skeat-Sisam (1956) assume) than an error for yEM as\n
emended by Smithers (1987). yE is quite frequently written for\n
yER in other eME hands and the supposition that it stands for\n
yEM would make this a unique example in Havelok of the \'Scandinavian\'\n
form for "them". There are a number {of examples in the text of\n
yEI/yEY for "they", but apparently only one of yERE for "their".\n
We know that "them" was the last of the set of three regularly\n
to appear in Middle English, so a form yEM in Havelok might\n
perhaps be unexpected beside so many examples of HEM. Whether\n
such forms were in the rather more northerly Lincolnshire\n
original is unknowable=}\n
$stand/vSpt13{rh}_STOD\n

$/AOd_A\n
$knife/nOd{rh}_KNIF\n
{=or KINF? The three minims could be read either way as far as shape is\n
concerned. On microfilm there appears to be a very faint oblique stroke\n
distanced from the minims but pointing towards the first. A check of the\n
original MS might clarify this. The scribe makes only occasional use of\n
oblique strokes on <i> and they are always rather faint and hard to\n
distinguish in individual cases on film from effects from the film\n
having picked up some texture from the parchment=}\n
{\\}\n

$/P13OdM_HIM\n
$ha:wian?/vpt13_HAU+EDE $/vpt13_+EDE\n
$/P13NM_HE\n
$e:ode/vpt13_YEDE\n
{=This is the worst problem of Smither\'s (1987) locus desperatus and the\n
Cambridge text is no longer running so supplies no help. Skeat-Sisam\n
(1956) emend heavily and frankly unjustifiably, to make a sensible\n
reading text but which cannot be arrived at from the MS readings\n
and is word substitution purely. The last two words are clearly\n
separated and I agree with the Skeat-Sisam reading HE YEDE\n
(retained by them in favour of emendation earlier in the line),\n
pace Smithers who insists on HEyEDE or HE yEDE, denying the\n
possibility of HE YEDE. The problem letter is \'y\'-shaped rather\n
than thorn-shaped, though undotted. It could ceteris paribus be\n
read as either Y or y - there is a cline of shapes and dotting\n
is not consistent. But HE yEDE makes no sense and Smithers\'\n
suggestion that the text should read HEyEDE from OE ae:Yan\n
"to conjure on oath, to exhort" needs a lot of special pleading. The\n
final E of the supposed past participle Smithers admits would be\n
\'an error\' (at least in this form of language) while a rhyme of an\n
unstressed final syllable on a (supplied) main verb - LEDE in the next\n
line would be unprecedented in the poem. My alternative suggestion is\n
that HAUEDE is not from "have" (thus obviating the necessity of\n
finding a dependent past participle) but is from OE ha:wian\n
"to regard, view, look on". (See MED s.v. hauen). We would\n
perhaps expect this scribe to spell the word *HAWEDE, especially\n
because of the ambiguity with "have", but there is a certain\n
amount of U W variation - for a parallel example see line 1402\n
SHEUE "show" (rhyming with KNEWE) and a reverse example LOWERD\n
"lord" in line 622. And/or, with the other signs of textual\n
corruption, the present scribe may not have understood the\n
word. But if we accept OE ha:wian, we would then have something\n
syntactically simple: "When the traitor was watching him he went\n
(so) that (i.e. "as if") he should lead him forth and drown him in\n
the sea". This would make the point that Godard saw him bind and gag\n
Havelok and make as if he were going to do the deed (which in the end\n
of course he didn\'t) but it brings more life to the story that Godard\n
had every confidence that the deed was about to be done and assumed\n
it then was=}\n
{\\}\n
$that/cj_*yAT\n

$/TN_yE\n
$name/n{rh}_NAME\n
{=The only way of parsing this that I can think of is "his, to whom\n
Havelok was the name". Unless yE NAME is an error for the much more\n
common TO NAME: "his, who Havelok was by name". Neither Smithers (1987)\n
nor Skeat-Sisam (1956) comment on the syntax=}\n
{\\}\n
$but/cj_*BUT\n
$ere/av_OR\n
$/P13NM_HE\n
$have/vpt13_HAU+EDE $/vpt13_+EDE\n
$much/ajOd_MICHEL\n
$shame/nOd{rh}_SHAME\n
{\\}\n
$much/ajOd_*MICHEL\n
$sorrow/nOd_SORWE\n
$&/cj_AND\n
$much/ajOd_MICHEL\n
$te:ona/nOd{rh}_TENE\n
{\\}\n
$&/cj_*AND\n
$thrice/av_yRIE\n
{="thrice" seems the only possible interpretation - so Smithers (1987).\n
Skeat emends to YETE. Smithers points out that Havelok only won England\n
once, so the sense is odd. Unless the yRIE refers to H winning the\n
country in spite of the 3 problems of shame, sorrow and te:ona. But\n
yRIE can hardly imply all that=}\n
$/P13NM_HE\n

$whale/nOd{rh}_HWEL\n
{=Smithers (1987) doesn\'t like the repetition of "whale" with a different\n
spelling. Nevertheless it seems to me that the present scribe\n
probably thought "whale" was intended in each case, with different\n
rhyme words justifying the different spellings. The original text\n
is perhaps less likely to have intended two whales, but if sorting\n
out the original is deemed necessary I\'d prefer the Skeat-Sisam\n
(1956) solution to Smithers\' one: HWEL is a "correction" (to give a word\n
for "whale") of HEL which was intended for "eel". At least "eel" was\n
a common fishing staple unlike Smithers\' putative Dutch "kwal"\n
"jellyfish" to explain QUAL=}\n
{\\}\n
$/P13NM_*HE\n

$give/vSpt13_YAS\n
{=sic - for "gave". See Smithers (1987) for the construction,\n
apparently a calque on Scandinavian "give sik illa" . The Y is\n
thorn-shaped but not more so than many others in the text.\n
Uncrossed F is the same shape as S and not infrequently appears\n
in texts for F, so Smithers\' emendation (following Stratmann)\n
to YAF is textually all right=}\n
$/P13OiXF_HIRE\n

$/P11Od_M\n
{=sic - for ME?=}\n
$with{w}/pr_WIT[H]\n
{=Only the ascender of H is written by the scribe so the word looks like WITL=}\n
$/P12<prX_yE\n
$to/pr_TO\n
;_DENEMAK\n
{=sic=}\n
$both/pnOd{rh}_BAyE\n
{=i.e. "take me with thee to Denmark both [of us together]". This\n
slightly corrupt line has caused problems. Skeat-Sisam (1956) have one\n
solution - to read NIMEN WIT for NIM IN WITL taking WIT to be the\n
only example in this text of the dual. I think this unlikely (though\n
compare Genesis and Exodus of similar date and provenance which uses\n
the dual a number of times). But NIM is very clearly followed by a\n
space and then three minims and WIT clearly has an ascender after it.\n
Smithers\' (1987) solution seems even more fanciful and clumsy however.\n
He reads NIM IN WIT LIyE and gives two possible interpretations -\n
"let us take our journey" - emending NIM IN to NIME, but prefers,\n
on the grounds of palaeographical likelihood, NIM IN ... TO "go to"\n
and WIT LIyE "with a body of men". My solution seems to me simpler\n
and more likely. The scribe often fails to finish words and the\n
three minims of "in" can equally well be read as M. The putative L\n
at the end of WIT is identical to an ascender of H and nothing else\n
need be supposed. The phrase "take me with thee" would then pick up\n
lines 1340-1 below "For I shall never be happy until I\'ve seen\n
Denmark with my eyes"=}\n
{\\}\n

or missing, X can therefore look identical to R=}\n

$have/vpt23_HAU+EDEN $/vpt23_+EDEN\n
$/TOd_yE\n
$kitthen?/vnOd_KIyy+ING $/vnOd_+ING\n
$deal/vpp{rh}_DEL+ED $/vpp[L]{rh}_+ED\n
{=This is a textual difficulty as the reading is uncertain and those\n
suggested do not correspond to known words. Skeat reads yE KILyING\n
and then simply emends to ILK yING. Smithers (1987) rightly\n
rejects such a violent emendation which makes no accounting of\n
the corruption. He also reads KILyING and evokes ON ky\'la "fill\n
one\'s belly with" and ky\'la o,l "tipple ale" and translates\n
"?liquor for tippling". MED reads KIWING and gives no suggestion\n
as to the reading. I don\'t see the reading as either KILyING or\n
KIWING. The difficulty is not the fourth letter which is clearly\n
thorn (ruling out KIWING). Even if it be read as a Y or as a wynn\n
it doesn\'t help us with the third letter. Its shape is not that of\n
L which this scribe makes with a strong upright ascender (leaning\n
forwards if anything rather than backwards and usually (though not\n
always) with a leading fork or splaying at the top and a slight\n
rightward hook at the foot. This stroke is backward-sloping and\n
is parallel to, and most like, the first stroke of the immediately\n
following thorn. I think the letters can only be read as a double\n
thorn. There is a common early Middle English scribal habit, with\n
double letters that have ascenders, of representing the first of the\n
two by the ascender only, the lobe or limb following the second\n
ascender standing for both lobes. This is most commonly seen with B in\n
e.g. the forms of the verb "to have" where HABBE looks like HALBE\n
(cf. *UBBE below, fol. 215va and line 2289 of Smithers\' (1987) and\n
WIKKE below, fol. 216va line 2459 of Smithers). If we read KIyyING\n
the word could be either from OE cy:Yan, meaning "acquaintanceship"\n
(cf. the use of the verbal noun with this meaning in Ancrene Riwle)\n
or more likely from the verb derived from cy:YYu - see MED s.v.\n
kitthen, where the translation could be "friendly relations, friendly\n
behaviour". The line would then be translated: "when they had shared\n
(participated in) (see MED delen sense 5) friendly behaviour"=}\n
{\\}\n

$who/pnpl_HWO\n
$/P22X_YOU\n
$hence/av_HEnNE\n
$flee/vps22{rh}_FLE $/vps22[V]_0\n
{*sj context*}\n
{=Emendation of YOU to NOU or to YOUR "of you" have both been suggested.\n
If emendation is avoided, I think YOU could be reflexive here. The\n
sense, following "come unto me" requires the lads to be the subject\n
here and so YOU cannot be the object. "Cursed be the man who may flee\n
(from) you" (which seems to be Smithers\' reading) would be technically\n
possible but formally and semantically odd. Whereas "Cursed be any of\n
you who hence flee" seems to fit the case and could just about be\n
encompassed by the syntax suggested, literally: "Cursed be (ye) who\n
yourselves hence flee=}\n

$waergan/vpp-pl{rh}_WEREW+ED $/vpp[W]-pl{rh}_+ED\n
{=This is taken by all editors so far to be the same word as WIRWED, six lines\n
below, from OE wirgan, wyrgan meaning "strangled, throttled". This seems to\n
me to be formally and semantically far less likely than that WEREWED is from\n
OE wiergan, waergan "to curse". (Note also that Smithers (1987) has\n
WEREWED correctly in the text but cites the form as WERWED in his\n
glossary). WIRWED in line 1922 is, however, doubtless from wyrgan and\n
has the <i>-spelling expected in the language of both the original of\n
Havelok and of the copying scribe (Lincs and W. Norfolk respectively).\n
The <e>-spelling in WEREWED might have been adopted as a form of wyrgan\n
for the sake of rhyme, but the sense "cursed" from wiergan, waergan\n
actually fits much better in the context of the verse: "A curse on who\n
feels pity - for they deserved it. What were they doing there (i.e. they\n
should never have been there), they were accursed (damned)" (i.e. they\n
had put themselves beyond redemption (or pity) by their own actions -\n
cf. the common phrase "wereged gastes"). Note also that Vices and\n
Virtues (Essex) has virtually the same form for the plural past\n
participle of waergan - wEREwEDE=}\n
{\\}\n
$so/av_*SO\n
$long/av_LONGE\n

$barat/n_BARET\n
$onwitan?/vps13-ct_ON-HWAT $on-/xp-v_ON-\n
$/P13GM_IS\n
$weald/nOd{rh}_WOLD\n
{=Editors have been able to make little of this. Skeat-Sisam (1956)\n
drastically rewrites to HWAT yIS BARET OWETH ON WOLD - "what\n
this strife signifies". Smithers (1987) is rightly cautious and\n
leaves the line unemended with the comment that the use of WOLD with\n
the verb "to be" is like ON valdr with verb "to be", meaning\n
"is responsible for". He gives no suggested translation and admits\n
that the line remains an enigma, so I\'m not sure that this takes\n
us any farther forward. My tentative suggestion is to take\n
(ON)-HWAT as the verb which is the simplest solution syntactically.\n
Since a present tense is required it cannot be a form of cweYan\n
- although HWAT appears twice for the pret sg of cweYan elsewhere\n
in the poem. It could only be a reverse spelling HW for W for the\n
verb witan "know, be aware of, show respect to". There is no OE evidence\n
for a verb onwitan, so one would have to assume that the Havelok\n
poet\'s predilection for separable prefix verbs allowed it - if so\n
that might have accounted for the subsequent corruption. It\'s not\n
very satisfactory but would give a sensible reading with little or\n
no need for emendation: "better it is that I go myself to see that\n
this strife (i.e. those involved in it) knows about (acknowledges)\n
his authority (significance, power)"}\n
{\\}\n
$than/cj_*yAnNE\n
$/P11N_I\n

$may/vpt13_MOUCTE\n
{=sic - as Skeat rightly reads, though he \'regularises\' to MOUHTE.\n
Smithers has MOUTHE matching previous versions of the word, and\n
he makes no comment. But the reading is clear. The C and T are\n
ligatured, the second stroke of C (which is clearly C-shaped not\n
T-shaped) combines as the cross stroke of T. The shaft of T is\n
exaggeratedly long, but it has no sign of the splaying or forking\n
at the top that is always visible on H, and no sign of any second\n
separate stroke forming a limb to indicate H=}\n
$wait/viFier_WAYT+E $/viFier_+E\n

of Smithers\' (1987) edition, and WIKKE below, fol. 216va line 2459 of\n

$thereof/av-k_yER-OFFE $of/pr-k_-OFFE\n
$tre:owian/vppK2{rh}_TROU+D $/vpp[V]K2{rh}_+D\n
{=MS CROUD which makes no sense, so the C is likely to be for T - the\n
letter shapes do sometimes interchange in this hand. Smithers (1987)\n
follows Skeat in emending to TROD to restore the rhyme with GOD. TROD is said\n
to be the past participle from Old East Norse tro\'a inf. and the TROUD\n
form is a compromise between that and the native tre:owian which I have\n
used as the lemma for the tag for the sake of comparison with other texts=}\n
{\\}\n

$slay/vSpt23_SLOW+EN $/vSpt23_+EN\n
{="were not his two brothers and five others [who] slew" i.e. "had not\n
his two brothers and five others slain". Smithers makes a very\n
complicated argument that *NE-WEREn is a corruption of a ME conjunction\n
NE-WERE. I prefer to take this as a normal usage of the past\n
subjunctive. Skeat supplies the word \'that\' before SLOWEN but it can\n
perhaps be understood within the context of this construction without\n
being editorially supplied=}\n
$of/pr_OF\n
$/P23G_HERE\n

$mixed/aj_MIX+ED $/vpp-aj_+ED\n
{="vile". Smithers (1987) says this form is from OE mix "dung" plus\n
adjectival suffix -ed < OE -ede. It is perhaps possible that this is\n
an adjective formed from the past participle of an unattested OE verb\n
*mixan "produce dung, defile, pollute" or a ME verb formed from the\n
noun, cf. MED s.v. mixed ppl. A possible further example of such a\n
verb (with rare metathesis) may be found in the Jesus version of O&N,\n
MYSKEy (see Laing 2007)=}\n

{=sic. Smithers (1987) and Skeat-Sisam (1956) read AUNLAZ, but the\n

$Ya:/av_*yO\n
$crask?/aj-av_CARSC\n
{=Or read CARST, TARST. Editors explain the form as a reduction of AT ARST\n
or TO ARST. I wonder whether it might originally have been a\n
corruption of an adverbial form from Scandinavian karskr - cf.\n
OI karskr, kaskr "swift, vigorous, strong". The editorial explanation\n
is a formal and textual anomaly. Whatever one may think of the formal\n
likelihood of TARST from TO ARST or AT ARST, semantically it seems\n
very unlikely. Godrich has already been locked in fierce combat with\n
Ubbe from morning till night, so can hardly be said "then first to\n
go against the Danish", whereas "fiercely, strongly" is exactly right.\n
See MED s.v. crask for variant spellings such as "crast" and "karsk"\n
making it logically feasible to extend the range to include e.g. the\n
spellings CARSC, CARST=}\n
$beginnan/vSpt13_BI+GAN $be-/xp-v_BI+\n
\'_GODRICH\n
$to/im+C_TO\n

$cweYan/vSpt13_*GUOT\n
{=sic - the illuminated capital is not like either of the illuminator\'s\n
usual forms for *Q - one with a tail extending horizontally to the right\n
from the floor of the body of the letter, the other with a long tail extending\n
downwards to the left of the body of the letter. This is an *O-shaped\n
letter with an element curling into the centre of it at the right hand\n
side - identical to the illuminated capital *Gs elsewhere. It is a one-line\n
blue initial *G decorated with red. No guide letter is visible. It is\n
not as large as the usual illuminated initials and it looks rather\n
squashed into the line space, so its presence may have been an afterthought.\n
This anomalous letter is not noted by Smithers (1987) who just prints *Q=}\n
\'_HAUELOK\n

\n
# 149\n
{Oxford, Bodleian Library, Laud Misc 636, fols. 88v-91v: Peterborough Chronicle, final continuation}\n
1154\n
519 298 W\n
{=Peterborough, N Northants (Soke of Peterborough)=}\n
{=Sample represents all the English in this hand=}\n
{=Script = C12 book hand combining elements of Anglo-Saxon minuscule and\n
Caroline minuscule=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{=The scribe has a very unusual way of abbreviating "that" as a lower\n
case D with a bar through the ascender. This form is also used (once only)\n
{by Scribe G of BL Egerton 613 (egpm1t.tag} and (twice only) by Scribe B\n
of Vices and Virtues (vvbt.tag). This usage seems to be based on the\n
very commonly employed practice of writing "that" as thorn with a cross bar\n
through the ascender. Since this scribe\'s realisation is identical to his\n
realisation of edh I have transcribed it as edh (i.e. lower case d\n
in my system). e-caudata (<e> with a cedilla-like hook beneath it)\n
is realised as E,=}\n
{~f88v~}\n
{=New hand starts about a third of the way down the verso. The top,\n
outer and bottom margins between fols. 86r and 90v contain a chronicle\n
in French in a hand of C13b (see Ker)=}\n

# 16\n
{Oxford, Bodleian Library, Rawlinson C 317, fol. 89v: Candet Nudatum Pectus}\n
C13a1\n
344 452 E\n
{=NW Lancs=}\n
{=Sample represents all the text in English in this hand=}\n
{=Script - small compressed cursive university book hand=}\n
{=Status - MS punctuation done; tagging notes and textual notes up to date=}\n
{~f89v~}\n
{=The whole folio is closely written Latin in the same hand as the\n
Candet text which first appears in Latin just over half way down the\n
folio  and then in English=}\n
{(*CANDET NUDATUm PECToris . RUBET CRUENTUm LATUS . TENSA AREnT \\\n
UISCerA . DECORA LANGUENT LUMINA . ORA PALLENT REGIA . ProCerA\n
RIGENT BRACHIA . CRURA PEn\\DENT . MORMORREA . RIGAT PEDES\n
TEREBRATOS BeatI SANGUinIS UNDA .(}\n
{=ins, in left margin, a hand with pointing finger indicating the\n
English text=}\n
{para}\n
